title: 106_hr5427
content: The Drug-Free Communities Support Program is added to Chapter 2 of the National Narcotics Leadership Act of 1988. The Drug-Free Communities Act is amended to increase funding for fiscal years 2003 to 2006 and adjust administrative cost limitations. The Drug-Free Communities Act is amended to increase funding to 3 percent for fiscal years 2003 through 2006. Section 1032 of the Act is modified to limit grant awards to $100,000 per fiscal year, with the possibility of maintaining funding at 100 percent in the second year upon successful reapplication. The grant recipient can maintain funding levels at 100% of the original award in the first year, 75% in the third year, and 50% in the fourth and fifth years upon successful reapplication. Exceptions apply for grants of $50,000 or less. The Administrator may not modify eligibility criteria for grant recipients who maintain funding levels based on the original award amount, with exceptions for grants of $50,000 or less. The Administrator cannot change eligibility criteria for grant renewal without consulting the Advisory Commission. SEC. 2. REPORTING REQUIREMENTS. The Director of the Office of National Drug Control Policy will conduct a study to evaluate the need for increased administrative costs for the Drug-Free Communities Act. A report including findings, current staffing levels, justification for any increase in administrative funds, and supported programs will be submitted to Congress within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The Director of the Office of National Drug Control Policy will provide a detailed report to Congress within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The report will include a description of how programs will enhance grant performance, application processing, and program support. It will also account for the amount of any increase in administrative funds used by Federal agencies and analyze expected outcomes. Measures to limit administrative costs in the future will be outlined. SEC. 3. ANTIDRUG COALITION INSTITUTE. The Director of the Office of National Drug Control Policy may grant funds to a national nonprofit organization to establish a National Community Antidrug Coalition Institute. The organization must have expertise in community antidrug coalitions and the Institute will provide education, training, and research to evaluate coalition performance. The National Community Antidrug Coalition Institute aims to evaluate coalition performance, bridge research and practice, and translate knowledge into practical information. $2,000,000 is authorized for grants in fiscal years 2002 and 2003.
